APCATA 15948 S0926-860X(16)30366-0 10.1016/j.apcata.2016.07.011 Elsevier B.V. Fig. 1 XRD patterns of HTC and C-EDA-x supports with different N content. Fig. 1 Fig. 2 XPS spectra of N 1s in Pt/C-EDA-1.0, Pt/C-EDA-2.3, Pt/C-EDA-4.1 and Pt/C-EDA-8.3 samples. Fig. 2 Fig. 3 Plot of relative intensity against the percentage of pyridine-type (N-6 ■), pyrrole-type (N-5 ●), and graphite-type (N-Q ▲) nitrogen species on the surface of C-EDA-x. Table 2 Sample Species Binding energy of N 1s (eV) Relative intensity (%) C-EDA-1 N-6 398.4 22.0 N-5 400.3 36.8 N-Q 401.3 41.2 C-EDA-2.3 N-6 398.7 27.9 N-5 400.7 36.9 N-Q 401.5 35.2 C-EDA-4.1 N-6 398.4 29.4 N-5 400.4 42.0 N-Q 401.3 28.6 C-EDA-8.3 N-6 398.2 40.9 N-5 400.2 35.6 N-Q 401.0 23.5 N-doped carbon supported Pt catalyst for base-free oxidation of 5-hydroxymethylfurfural to 2,5-furandicarboxylic acid Xuewang Han a Chaoqun Li a Yong Guo b ⁎ Xiaohui Liu a Yongguang Zhang b Yanqin Wang a ⁎ a Shanghai Key Laboratory of Functional Materials Chemistry, Research Institute of Industrial Catalysis, East China University of Science and Technology, Meilong Road 130, Shanghai, 200237, PR China Shanghai Key Laboratory of Functional Materials Chemistry Research Institute of Industrial Catalysis East China University of Science and Technology Meilong Road 130 Shanghai 200237 PR China b Research Institute of Petroleum Processing (RIPP), Sinopec, 18 Xueyuan Road 18, P.O. Box 914-12, Beijing 100083, PR China Research Institute of Petroleum Processing (RIPP) Sinopec 18 Xueyuan Road 18 P.O. Box 914-12 Beijing 100083 PR China ⁎ Corresponding authors. Graphical abstract A new kind of N-doped carbon supported Pt catalyst (Pt/C) has been prepared for the selective oxidation of 5-Hydroxymethylfurfural (HMF) to 2,5-Furandicarboxylic Acid (FDCA) in base-free conditions. The catalyst (Pt/C-EDA-x) prepared by using ethylenediamine (EDA) as nitrogen source showed higher activity than those prepared by N,N-dimethylaniline (DMA), ammonia (NH3) or acetonitrile (ACN) as nitrogen sources. The Pt/C-EDA-4.1 catalyst showed the highest activity in the oxidation of HMF to FDCA and as high as 96.0% FDCA was obtained under optimal reaction conditions (110°C, 1.0MPa O2, 12h). The samples were characterized by XRD, XPS, CO2-TPD, TEM, SEM, and elemental analysis. XPS results showed that the pyridine-type nitrogen (N-6) played a key role in the selective oxidation of HMF, which can be attributed to the basicity of N-6 site. CO2-TPD measurements also showed that the involving of N elements in catalyst preparation introduced a new kind of medium basic site on the support surface. The influence of reaction time, catalyst dosage, and temperature on the HMF oxidation to FDCA catalyzed by Pt/C-EDA-4.1 was studied. Keywords N-doped carbon Base-free oxidation 2,5-Furandicarboxylic acid 1 Introduction The strong demands for alternate resources to obtain chemicals, which are produced from fossil feedstocks, attracted researchers to work on the renewable resource [1,2]. Biomass, as a renewable resource, has been demonstrated as promising feedstock for the production of chemicals in the future, which can be converted to bulk products, such as liquid fuels, or high value-added chemicals, including glucose, 5-hydroxymethylfurfural (HMF), levulinic acid and glycerine through bio-refinery processes [3–5]. Among the variety of biomass-derived platform molecules, HMF, produced by glucose or fructose dehydration, is seen as a key precursor for bio-renewable chemicals and materials production [6–8] and its selective oxidation to 2,5-furandicarboxylic acid (FDCA) is an attractive route, as these furan products could be used as pharmaceuticals and polymer precursors [9,10]. The molecule of FDCA contain furyl ring and carboxyl groups in the basic structure, which structure is similar to that of terephthalic acid, thus it would be a possible replacement monomer for pure terephthalic acid (PTA) used to produce polyethylene terephthalate (PET) [11,12]. Traditionally, the aerobic oxidation of HMF to FDCA was carried out by using potassium permanganate as stoichiometric oxidant which have toxicity issues and produce a large amount of pollutants [13]. There are also some studies reported that homogeneous catalysts such as Co/Mn/Br in corrosive solvents (e.g., acetic acid) can be utilized for the oxidation of HMF, which is widely used for the efficient oxidation of paraxylene (PX) to PTA [14]. However, the homogeneous catalysts showed some disadvantages, like the difficulty in catalyst recycling and the pollution to environment. On the contrary, it has more advantages by using heterogeneous catalyst, since it overcomes the drawbacks of homogeneous catalysts. Recently, there have been several reports on the aerobic oxidation of HMF to FDCA over supported transition metal catalysts, including Pt, Pd, Au, Ru, and Cu loaded on various supports, like carbon, hydrotalcite, TiO2, Al2O3, etc in basic solution [15–20]. For example, Casanova et al. [21] reported that HMF could be selectively converted into FDCA over gold nanoparticles supported on CeO2 and TiO2 in NaOH solution under mild conditions (65–130°C, 10bar air). Davis et al. [22] reported the catalytic activity of supported Pt, Pd and Au catalysts at 22°C and high pH in a semi-batch reactor and found that FDCA was formed over Pt/C and Pd/C, but 5-hydroxymethyl-2-furancarboxylic acid (HMFCA) was formed over Au/C and Au/TiO2. In addition, there are some reports on the use of alloy catalysts in the oxidation reaction of HMF, to obtain good results. Some interesting works demonstrated that alloy catalysts such as Au-Cu, Au-Pd supported on various carriers showed excellent reactivity [20,23–25]. Similar to Au, Pd and alloy catalysts, supported Pt catalysts were also found to be active toward the aerobic oxidation of HMF into FDCA in the earliest, and are still widely investigated now. Verdeguer et al. [26] reported that full HMF conversion was achieved by using Pt/C and Pt-Pb/C catalysts in a strongly alkaline aqueous medium with FDCA yields of 81 and 99%, respectively. A mechanistic investigation involving kinetic modeling has been partly elucidated using ionic polymer stabilizer afforded Pt nanoparticles for the oxidation of HMF under mild conditions by Siankevich and co-workers and found that the IP-modified surface led to a higher conversion rate at an early phase of the reaction and 18O atoms come from H2 18O involved in the reaction and incorporated in FDCA [27]. Moreover, Rass et al. [28] reported the oxidation of HMF to FDCA in moderately basic aqueous solutions over activated carbon supported Pt and Pt-Bi catalysts and found that Bi can enhance the activity and stability of the Pt/C catalyst, as well as the selectivity to FDCA. It can be seen that most studies focused on adding extra homogeneous base to promote the oxidation reaction. Recently, the development of new solid base catalysts for HMF oxidation without adding homogeneous base in reaction medium has received widely attention, because it may effectively reduce the risk of equipment corrosion [29,30]. Gupta and co-workers developed a hydrotalcite-supported gold nanoparticle (Au/HT) catalyst for selective oxidation of HMF into FDCA using molecular oxygen in water under homogeneous base-free condition [31]. The catalyst showed excellent activity at 95°C, but the stability of the catalyst decreased gradually, because of the instability of the hydrotalcite in water. Wang et al. [30] demonstrated the base-free aerobic oxidation of HMF into FDCA by using carbon nanotube (CNT) supported Au-Pd alloy catalyst in water and found that the carbon nanotube-enhanced adsorption and the alloying effect are mainly contributed to the realization of the base-free oxidation reaction. Han et al. [32] developed an efficient Pt/COMg catalyst for the oxidation of HMF to FDCA in aqueous solution without adding homogeneous base and found that it exhibited excellent selectivity and stability. The yield of FDCA reached 97%. The excellent activity may come from the formation of COMg bond, which was a new basic site and promoted the activation of hydroxyl and the formation of an intermediate, hemiacetal in the aerobic oxidation reaction. There are also some other interesting catalysts being reported for the aerobic oxidation of HMF to FDCA in base-free condition. For Example, Corma et al. reported the oxidative esterification of HMF to 2,5-dimethylfuroate by using Au-CeO2 under mild conditions in the absence of any base [16]. In addition, Ru-K-OMS-2 has also been demonstrated to exhibit catalytic activity in base-free conditions, which gave a maximum yield of 66% of FDCA [33]. However, the metal oxide catalyst was unstable during the reaction in high temperature aqueous solution. Therefore, the development of stable heterogeneous catalysts for the oxidation of HMF under base-free conditions remains challenging. As compared with metal oxide, carbon materials exhibit very high hydrothermal stability. Recently, Ru/C and Ru clusters supported on covalent triazine frameworks (Ru/CTFs) were reported as stable catalysts for the oxidation of HMF under base-free conditions [34,35]. But these two catalysts did not exhibit excellent catalytic activity, and the yield of FDCA was lower than 90%. N-doped carbons are well recognized and used in photocatalysis, anode materials in lithium battery, supercapacitor and catalyst, but never used as support in the selective oxidation of HMF to FDCA under base-free condition [36–38]. Herein, we designed a simple nitrogen doped carbon catalyst via hydrothermal method for the base-free oxidation of HMF into FDCA under mild conditions (110°C, O2 1.0MPa, 12h). Then these prepared catalysts were characterized with XPS, TPD, XRD, SEM, TEM and BET in order to understand the effects of the catalyst properties on the catalytic activities. The influence of reaction time, catalyst dosage, and temperature on the HMF oxidation to FDCA catalyzed by Pt/C-EDA-4.1 was also studied. 2 Experimental section 2.1 Materials 5-Hydroxymethylfurfural (HMF) (>98%) was purchased from DEMO Medical, 2,5-Diformylfuran (DFF) (>98%), 5-formyl-2-furancarboxylic acid (FFCA) (>98%), 2,5-furandicarboxylic (FDCA) (>97%) were purchased from TCI. Chloroplatinic acid [(H2PtCl6)·6H2O] was obtained from Alfa-Aesar. Other chemical reagents, such as Glucose, Ethylenediamine, Resorcinol, etc., were obtained from SCRC. 2.2 Catalyst preparation A series of nitrogen doped carbon materials were prepared by hydrothermal method. A typical synthesis procedure is as following: 4g of glucose, 4g of resorcinol, 1g of ethylenediamine (EDA) and 10g of H2O were mixed in a 100mL flask and stirred for 1h. Then, the mixture was sealed into an autoclave and put into an oven at 180°C for 24h for hydrothermal treatment. After reaction, the autoclave was cooled down in a cold water bath and a black solid was obtained. Then the obtained black solid was filtered and washed with distilled water for several times until the filtrate was colorless. Finally, the black solid was carbonated in nitrogen flow of 30cm3 min−1 at 800°C for 3h after drying. Thus-obtained nitrogen-containing carbons were named as C-EDA. Afterwards, we also synthesized a series of C-EDA materials with different nitrogen content by changing the dosage of ethylenediamine, and then named as C-EDA-x. As a contrast, other nitrogen-doped carbons were also synthesized in the same way as C-EDA by using N,N-dimethylaniline (DMA), ammonia (NH3) or acetonitrile (ACN) as nitrogen source, respectively. As a comparison, hydrothermal carbon (HTC) catalyst was also synthesized by a hydrothermal method and further carbonization, by using glucose and resorcinol as carbon sources. Platinum was loaded by impregnation with an aqueous solution of H2PtCl6 followed by reduction. An aqueous solution of H2PtCl6 containing the required amount of Pt (5wt%) was added dropwise under stirring to an aqueous suspension of support. After that, the mixture was ultrasonically treated for 0.5h to ensure the solid being uniformly dispersed. Then excess amount of NaBH4 was slowly added to the mixture with stirring under room temperature. The solid phase were finally separated by filtration and washed with deionized water for several times, and then dried in a vacuum desiccator at 60°C. 2.3 Catalyst characterization methods Elemental analyses were performed on Elementar's Vario EL III microanalyzer. C, H, and N values were calculated as per atomic weight of C=12.01, H=1.008,N=14.007, and O=15.999. The values obtained for each element were expressed as a percentage of the total molecular weight of the compound. The synthesized catalysts were fully characterized by the following methods: Powder X-ray diffraction (XRD) patterns were collected in the θ-2θ mode using a Bruker D8 Focus diffractometer (CuKa1 radiation, k=1.5406Å), operated at 40kV and 40mA with scattering angles (2θ) of 8−60°. X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) was performed using a Thermo ESCA LAB-250 spectrometer with monochromatic Al Ka radiation, and the XPS results were calibrated using the C 1s peak at 284.8eV. XPS Peak 4.1 was employed to deconvolve the N 1s peaks using the Shirley-type baseline and an iterative least-squared optimization algorithm. Nitrogen sorption isotherms were measured at −196°C with a NOVA 4200e sorption analyzer. Before the measurements, the samples were degassed at 100°C in vacuum for 8h. The Brunauer-Emmett-Teller (BET) method was utilized to calculate the apparent surface area. Temperature programmed desorption of carbon dioxide (CO2-TPD) was carried out on Micromeritics AutoChem 2920 equipped with mass spectrometry using quadrupole spectrometer (MS OmniStar). 100mg of catalyst was placed in quartz sample tube. Before TPD experiments, the catalysts were outgassed at 500°C for 2h in a flow of helium. Subsequently the catalysts were cooled down to 50°C and treated with a CO2 flow for 60min. Weak adsorbed CO2 was removed by flushing with He at 50°C for 60min. The desorption of CO2 was measured by heating the catalyst from 50°C to 600°C at a heating rate of 10°Cmin−1 in He flow. The desorbed products were analyzed by mass spectrometry. The number of basic sites was calculated from the CO2 peaks (the molecular ion, m/z =44). Scanning electronic microscope (SEM) images were obtained from JEOL JSM–63602V and Hitachi S-3400N microscope operated at 5kV or 15kV, respectively. Transmission electron microscopy (TEM) images were recorded on a FEI TECNAI F20 s-TWIN instrument, and the electron beam accelerating voltage was 200kV. Chemical analysis of the samples was performed by using inductively coupled plasma atomic emission spectrometry (ICP-AES). 3 Reaction procedure and product analysis The oxidation reaction of HMF was performed in a batch-type Teflon-lined stainless-steel autoclave (100mL), equipped with an internal thermo-controller and pressure gauge. In a typical catalytic experiment, 0.04g of catalysts, 10mL of aqueous solution of HMF (0.05M) were added to a stirred autoclave reactor. Initially, the system was filled with 1.0MPa of oxygen at room temperature, and then it begins to heat up. After the system reaches the required temperature, the reaction starts by stirring with a magnetic stirrer. When the reaction was finished, the mixture was made alkaline by adding a certain amount of sodium hydrate so that the crystalline FDCA can be completely dissolved for accurate analysis, followed by analysis using HPLC (Agilent 1200 series, Bio-Rad Aminex HPX–87H column, 300mm×7.8mm×9μm). A 0.004M H2SO4 mobile phase was employed as mobile phase at 55°C with a flow rate of 0.45mLmin−1. The yields of FDCA and intermediate products were based on conversion of HMF and confirmed by calibration of standard solutions of the reactants and products. 4 Results and discussion 4.1 Characterization of catalysts The textural structures of catalysts are measured and summarized in Table 1 . The calculated specific surface area of HTC is 434m2 g−1, while the specific surface area of nitrogen-doped carbons decreased gradually from 67 to 20m2 g−1 with increasing N content from 1.0 to 8.3wt%. The lower specific surface area could be attributed to higher polymerization degree of carbon and nitrogen sources. The chemical composition of various carbon samples prepared by using different nitrogen sources were detected by an elemental analyzer and the results are also shown in Table 1. In order to investigate the effect of nitrogen content, the C-EDA-x samples, with different nitrogen contents from 1.0 to 8.3wt% prepared by adding different amounts of EDA in the hydrothermal process, were also characterized and summarized in Table 1. The N content of C-NH3 and C-DMA was 3.8 and 3.2wt%, respectively. However, the N content of C-ACN (0.3wt%) was lower than mentioned above due to only a small amount of nitrogen atoms enter the carbon skeleton. The level of structural order in the carbonaceous materials was checked using XRD measurements (Fig. 1 ). For all supports, two broad peaks are observed at around 20°–30°, and 43.4°, assigned to (002) and (100) graphite planes, respectively, which shows the amorphous carbon structure. Furthermore, we can see the obvious shift towards higher angles of (002) reflection compared with that of HTC, indicating a significant decrease in the interlayer spacing. The peak shifts gradually to the higher diffraction-angle side with increasing nitrogen content (23.5° for C-EDA-1, 24.1° for C-EDA-4.1, and 24.2° for C-EDA-8.3 compared to 23.1° for HTC), and can be directly related to the much smaller size of the nitrogen atom than that of carbon atoms. Therefore, nitrogen doping resulted in more defects and disorder in the structure of supports, which may become structural basis of the active sites [39,40]. The catalytic activity was measured over various catalysts summarized in Table 1. It can be found that the catalyst prepared by using EDA as nitrogen source had the highest activity. In addition, we also compared the activity of Pt/-C-EDA-4.1 and conventional supported Pt catalysts in Table 1. It can be found that the catalytic activity of Pt/C-EDA in the absence of base conditions is comparable to that of the conventional supported Pt catalysts in the presence of base. It is also necessary to eliminate the effect of nitrogen content of different catalysts on the catalytic activity. Accordingly, we synthesized Pt/C-ACN-0.6 and Pt/C-NH3-4.9 by adjusting the amount of nitrogen sources added, and tested their catalytic activity, which results shown in Table S1. When using Pt/C-EDA-4.1 as catalyst, the conversion of HMF reached 88.4%, while the yields of FDCA and FFCA were 18.3 and 50.7%, respectively, after reaction for 4h. However, for the Pt/C-ACN-0.6 and Pt/C-NH3-4.9, both the conversion of HMF and the yield of intermediates are relatively low compared to Pt/C-EDA-4.1 after reaction for 4h. We extended the reaction time for 18h using Pt/C-NH3-4.9 as catalyst so that the HMF and intermediate products could completely transformed into FDCA, and the results showed that the selectivity to FDCA was only 77.4% (low carbon balance because of partial polymerization). Therefore, prolonging the reaction time cannot improve the selectivity of FDCA to reach as high as Pt/C-EDA-4.1, which means that the nature of these catalysts is obviously different. It is proved once again that the Pt/C-EDA-4.1 catalyst has excellent catalytic activity and high FDCA selectivity. In order to study the relationship between the nitrogen species and the reaction activity, we characterized the samples by X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS). Fig. 2 and Fig. S1 shows the detailed spectra corresponding to the experimental and curve fitted N 1s spectra of each catalyst. In the N 1s spectra, three peaks with electron-binding energies of 401.4±0.5, 400.3±0.3 and 398.6±0.3eV have been observed after deconvolution and can be attributed to graphene-type nitrogen (N-Q), pyrrole-type nitrogen (N-5) and pyridine-type nitrogen (N-6), respectively [41]. Table 2 and Table S2 summarize the binding energies (eV) and relative intensities (%) of each N species as observed from the respective N 1s spectrum of various samples. For the sample with 1.0wt%N (C-EDA-1.0), the relative intensity of N-6, N-5 and N-Q were 22.0, 36.8 and 41.2%, respectively, which has a lowest yield of FDCA (80.4%). An interesting phenomenon is that the more nitrogen in the catalyst, the higher the catalytic activity. Indeed, the 5wt% Pt/C-EDA-4.1 and Pt/C-EDA-8.3 (5wt%) catalysts exhibited better catalytic activity. Therefore, we analyzed the relationship between the catalytic activity and the relative content of nitrogen species. Fig. 3 is the plot of relative intensity against the percentage of pyridine-type (N-6), pyrrole-type (N-5) and graphite-type (N-Q) nitrogen species on the surface of C-EDA-x detected by XPS. With increasing nitrogen content, the proportion of N-6 in all nitrogen atoms gradually increased, and a significant increase of FDCA yield was detected. It is notable that when the relative intensity of N-6 and N-5 was equal, the catalyst showed highest activity. A negative correlation could be observed between the yield of FDCA and the relative content of graphite-type nitrogen species. The catalyst activity cannot be correlated with the relative amount of pyrrole-type nitrogen species. Thus, through the above discussion, we can deduce that the N-6 play a key role in the selective oxidation of HMF, which can be attributed to the basicity of N-6 site confirmed by CO2-TPD later. Fig. 4 showed the possible positions of N species doped on carbon [42]. The basicity of all the supports was detected via CO2-TPD and the result was shown in Fig. 5 . It can be seen that the adsorption of CO2 on C-DMA, C-NH3, and C-ACN occurs via the weak chemical interaction of CO2 molecules with nitrogen groups at the temperature of less than 100°C, suggesting the existence of weak basic sites. On the contrary, the desorption of CO2 on C-EDA-x at a temperature higher than 100°C is due to chemically adsorbed CO2, which means that involving N in catalyst preparation introduced a new medium strength basic site in the carbonaceous materials. Obviously, the CO2 desorption peak area increased significantly with the increase of nitrogen content in the C-EDA-x, which may be attributed to the increase of absolute amount of N-6 species. Previous studies mentioned that basic sites on the surface of catalyst could promote the activation of hydroxyl and the formation of intermediate hemiacetal in oxidation reaction of alcohols [29,31,43,44]. Indeed, this kind of Pt/C-EDA-4.1 catalyst had a best activity for HMF oxidation under base-free conditions due to alkalinity from pyridine-type nitrogen. 4.2 Influence of various reaction conditions on the catalytic activity of Pt/C-EDA-4.1 on HMF oxidation The time course of the conversion of HMF catalyzed by Pt/C-EDA-4.1 is shown in Fig. 6 (a). Yields of FFCA and DFF accumulated to 33.8 and 11.3% at the first 4h and then diminished gradually as the reaction processed; this indicates that HMF was oxidized rapidly to DFF and FFCA, then gradually transferred to FDCA, and finally the yield of FDCA reached 96% after reaction for 12h. This reaction pathway is in agreement with the literature [28]. The influence of reaction catalyst dosage, temperature and O2 pressure on the HMF oxidation to FDCA catalyzed by Pt/C-EDA-4.1 was also studied, and the experiments were carried out at 10, 20, 40mg and 70, 90, 110°C, respectively. As shown in Fig. 6(b), it is clear that the catalyst dosage had a significant effect on the oxidation of HMF to FDCA. The yield of FDCA increased notably when the catalyst dosage increased from 10 to 40mg. A good HMF conversion of 99% and a 49.2% yield of FDCA were obtained after 12h by the use 10mg of Pt/C-EDA-4.1. With a further increase in catalyst dosage from 10 to 40mg, FDCA yield gradually increased, reaching 96% after 12h. These result means that the catalytic sites of 40mg of Pt/C-EDA-4.1were sufficient to absorb the HMF and facilitate the oxidation reaction. Fig. 6(c) shows the influence of the temperature with respect to the HMF conversion and the products yield. Remarkably, the aerobic oxidation of HMF was sensitive to the reaction temperature. The higher the reaction temperature was, the higher the FDCA yield was. When the reaction was performed under 70°C, the yield of FDCA was not more than 60% in 12h. When the temperature was raised to 110°C, the yield of FFCA gradually decreased from 38 to 0% meanwhile the yield of FDCA increased from 55.8 to 96%. Therefore, higher reaction temperature promoted the conversion of HMF to FDCA. The high catalytic activity of Pt/C-EDA-4.1 on the oxidation of HMF was tested with different oxygen pressure under base-free conditions (Fig. 6(d)). At a lower pressure (0.25MPa), the intermediate product was detected, meaning that the oxidation process was incomplete. On further increasing the reaction pressure to 0.5 and 1.0MPa, the activity of catalyst increased gradually and a higher FDCA yield was obtained without any FFCA was detected. The above results were consistent with the previous reports on platinum catalyzed oxidation of HMF to DFF [28]. The proposed pathways for the oxidation of HMF are shown in Scheme 1 . In the initial stage of the reaction, the substrate quickly transformed to DFF, then subsequently oxidized to FFCA via hydration of aldehyde to hemiacetal catalyzed by the basic sites on the surface of Pt/C-EDA-4.1. Similarly, the formed FFCA can be further oxidized to FDCA by the way of the formation of the intermediate hemiacetal [29,31,42,43]. 4.3 Catalyst stability and reusability The stability and reusability of the Pt/C-EDA-4.1 catalyst was investigated by reusing the catalyst in consecutive catalytic runs. In each run, the catalyst was separated from the reaction mixture by high-speed centrifugation, washed with water, and was then filtered and reused without further treatment in the following run. As shown in Fig. 7 , HMF conversion was gradually decreased from 88.4% in the first run to 75.9% in the fifth run. FDCA yield was also decreased from 18.3% in the first run to 8.1% in the fifth run. This may be due to the leaching and oxidation of Pt nanoparticles, as appeared in previous report [28]. In order to reveal the intrinsic cause of the catalyst activity decrease, the spent catalyst was characterized by TEM, SEM, and XPS (Fig. 8 and Fig. S2). As seen in Fig. 8(a) and (b), a comparison of SEM images between the fresh and the spent catalyst confirmed that the catalyst showed no morphological change. However, there was clear growth or aggregation of Pt particles (from 4.06 to 5.42nm) after stability tests under base-free conditions based on TEM image and histogram of the Pt particle size distribution (Fig. 8c–f). In addition, the spent catalyst analyzed by ICP and Elemental analysis revealed that the platinum loading decreased from 5.1wt% to 4.3wt% and the nitrogen content decreased from 4.1wt% to 3.7wt%. Although the precious metal and nitrogen content decreased, there was no obvious change in the proportion of platinum valence state and three nitrogen species (Fig. S2). Thus, the most possible reason for the slight decrease of the catalytic activity was due to the slight leaching of Pt, N and the growth of Pt nanoparticles during the recycling procedures. The leaching and growth of Pt nanoparticles would be prevented by carbothermal reduction [45], this work is still in progress. 5 Conclusions In summary, N-doped carbon supported Pt catalyst (Pt/C-EDA-x) was successfully prepared via hydrothermal method by using glucose and resorcinol as carbon sources and EDA as nitrogen source. Several types of nitrogen elements, inclulding graphene-type nitrogen (N-Q), pyrrole-type nitrogen (N-5) and pyridine-type nitrogen (N-6), were successfully introduced into the carbon structure which was detected by XPS. Meanwhile, nitrogen doping resulted in more defects and disorder in the structure of supports, which may become structural basis of the active sites. The alkalinity of C-EDA-x was detected by CO2-TPD, which means that involving N in catalyst preparation introduced a new medium strength basic site on the support surface. Moreover, the increasing of nitrogen content has an obvious improvement effect, which makes the catalyst has higher N-6 proportion, more basic sites, and higher alkalinity, and facilitates the HMF oxidation to FDCA under base-free aqueous solution. Several reaction conditions were studied to optimize the reaction conditions on the HMF oxidation to FDCA catalyzed by Pt/C-EDA-4.1. In addition, the possible reason for the decrease of the catalytic activity was due to the slight leaching of Pt, N and the growth of Pt nanoparticles during the recycling procedures. coredata.dc:description: A new kind of N-doped carbon supported Pt catalyst (Pt/C) has been prepared for the selective oxidation of 5-Hydroxymethylfurfural (HMF) to 2,5-Furandicarboxylic Acid (FDCA) in base-free conditions. The catalyst (Pt/C-EDA-x) prepared by using ethylenediamine (EDA) as nitrogen source showed higher activity than those prepared by N,N-dimethylaniline (DMA), ammonia (NH3) or acetonitrile (ACN) as nitrogen sources. The Pt/C-EDA-4.1 catalyst showed the highest activity in the oxidation of HMF to FDCA and as high as 96.0% FDCA was obtained under optimal reaction conditions (110°C, 1.0MPa O2, 12h). The samples were characterized by XRD, XPS, CO2-TPD, TEM, SEM, and elemental analysis. XPS results showed that the pyridine-type nitrogen (N-6) played a key role in the selective oxidation of HMF, which can be attributed to the basicity of N-6 site. CO2-TPD measurements also showed that the involving of N elements in catalyst preparation introduced a new kind of medium basic site on the support surface. The influence of reaction time, catalyst dosage, and temperature on the HMF oxidation to FDCA catalyzed by Pt/C-EDA-4.1 was studied.
coredata.dc:title: N-doped carbon supported Pt catalyst for base-free oxidation of 5-hydroxymethylfurfural to 2,5-furandicarboxylic acid
